#Text=Kidnappers release two aid workers in Darfur , Sudan after more than 100 days
#Text=Monday , October 19 , 2009
#Text=The western region of DarfurImage : ChrisO .

#Text=Two members of Irish aid agency GOAL , kidnapped in Sudan 's Darfur region last July , were freed on Sunday , and are " in good health , " according to Abdel Baqi al-Jailani Sudan 's Minister for Humanitarian Affairs .
#Text=Sharon Commins and Hilda Kawuki say they are " thrilled " to be free at last .
#Text=Capture and release
#Text=Irish citizen Commins , 32 , and her Ugandan colleague Hilda Kawuki , 42 , were working for GOAL in a compound run by the charity in the North Darfur town of Kutum .
#Text=Armed men seized them on July 3 .

#Text=Following their release early Sunday morning they described their captivity as a " difficult time " , and thanked everyone who had worked to secure their freedom in a joint statement released through the GOAL .
#Text=They were , " naturally thrilled to be released after such a long period in captivity " .
#Text="

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=We know it must have been a traumatic period for our families especially and for our friends ,  they said .

_	_	_	_

#Text=It was of course , a difficult time - but we found strength in each other and in our friendship .

#Text=John O'Shea , president of GOAL , told AFP by telephone that ,  [ w]e are all relieved , " and that all at the charity were particularly happy for their families .

#Text=Countering claims earlier in the year that the kidnappers demanded US$ 2 ( € 1.34 ) million for the pair 's release , al-Gilani stressed  no ransom was paid , " . adding that local tribal chiefs pressured the kidnappers into freeing the aid workers .

column1: #Text=Increased hostility and threats
#Text=The captors held the two aid workers for over 100 days , the longest-running kidnapping in Darfur since the 2003 start of the region 's conflict .
#Text=Until March , the longest an aid worker had been detained in Darfur was 24 hours .

#Text=Following the issue of an arrest warrant in March by the International Criminal Court for Sudan 's President Omar al-Bashir for masterminding war crimes , aid workers say hostility and threats have increased towards them , and that Sudan 's relations with foreign relief organisations have declined dramatically .

#Text=In March and April two civil workers of Médecins Sans Frontières ( Doctors Without Borders ) and French aid agency Aide médicale internationale ( International Medical Aid ) were kidnapped then released after three and 26 days respectively .
#Text=A different group still holds captive two employees of the region 's joint United Nations — African Union peacekeeping force .
#Text=These are the only two workers left in captivity .
#Text=No amnesty
#Text=To date , Sudanese authorities have not punished kidnappers ; however al-Gilani announced yesterday that those responsible for the latest kidnapping must be brought to justice .
#Text=In talking with AFP , he stated , " [ t]hey must be punished otherwise there will be no more order " .
#Text=The government called the kidnappers " bandits " and state no amnesty will be granted for the release of aid workers .
